project.name: Binary Demonstration
project.notes: This application was made as part of a coding summer camp to help campers convert from binary (base 2) to decimal. They are only expected to use this application to aid them, and they do not need to view or edit the app's code. Conversion to decimal is done by taking the place value of the bits that are 1, and adding them up. This application helps to visualize the mathematical sum that needs to be performed to obtain the number in decimal. The top of the screen shows seven bits which can be toggled between 0 and 1. This subsequently affects the lower portion of the screen, lighting up the values that need to be added in order to reach the number in decimal. The application is also equipped with a "Restricted Mode" which is enabled by default. When enabled, the readout at the bottom showing the final sum will be disabled, and only show "??". It will, however, show the true answer if one of the three buttons on the left is pushed, to set the bits to all 0s, all 1s, or to randomize an example. These buttons are provided so that they can be pushed for a full example of the steps needed, but they are not given the sum for free when working with their actual values.

scene.name: Binary Demonstration
scene.notes: This application was made as part of a summer camp at UBC Geering Up Engineering Outreach, to help campers convert from binary (base 2) to decimal. Campers are only expected to use this application to aid them, and they do not need to view or edit the app's code. Conversion to decimal is done by taking the place value of the bits that are 1, and adding them up. This application helps campers visualize the mathematical sum that needs to be performed to obtain the number in decimal. The top of the screen shows seven bits which can be toggled between 0 and 1. This subsequently affects the lower portion of the screen, lighting up the values that need to be added in order to reach the number in decimal. The application is also equipped with a "Restricted Mode" which is enabled by default. When enabled, the readout at the bottom showing the final sum will be disabled, and only show "??". It will, however, show the true answer if one of the three buttons on the left is pushed, to set the bits to all 0s, all 1s, or to randomize an example. These buttons are provided so that campers can push them for a full example of the steps needed, but they are not given the sum for free when working with their actual values.

block.comment: Turn off this variable to disable Restricted Mode. When in Restricted Mode, the final result will only be shown if one of the three buttons on the left (All 0, All 1, or Random Example) are used. Otherwise, the final answer will be hidden and show as "??".
